titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Hudelist, the Austrian Chargé des Affairs called upon me for a certificate— In the Evening at the play— Schiller’s Piccolomini, a play somewhat long and tedious upon the stage, said to be better suited to be read.

2. Lesson in the morning from Mr: Catel— The study of German begins excessively to weary my patience. In the Evening again at the play— Saw Wallenstein’s Death, being the remainder of yesterday’s play. The poet has indeed written three parts of this History; but the first entitled Wallenstein’s camp is not allowed to be represented here, because it exhibits an army in mutiny.— The performance of this Evening is yet colder and more unsuitable for the stage than that of yesterday.

3. Visit this morning from Mr: Murray, who brought me a letter of recommendation from Mr: King. Finished reading Wieland’s Oberon, which is one of the best things I have read in German— Latter part of the Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Count Brühl and his family there— Played Chess with him.— Looking over a book which Dr: Brown lent me, Astle’s History of writing— Found there a couple of letter founder’s bills, in it—French and English— It suggested one trace for discovering any cypher in those two languages, consisting merely of figures to represent letters.

4. Called this forenoon upon Mr: Hudelist, the Austrian Chargé des Affairs, with the certificate which he wanted— Afterwards upon Mr Murray at the Ville de Paris.— Introduced him at the Casino. Countess P. Neale called in the evening to take leave of Mrs: Adams. She sets out early to-morrow morning with her father for England.— Read the Franklin’s tale in Chaucer.

5. Walking this day under the trees, met the Chevalier d’Aguilar, who has spent the Summer in Sweden and Denmark— Walk’d with him— In the Evening at Madame de Soldern’s— A large company— Played Whist with Madame Lubinska, M. de Massenbach and Mr: Knoblauch. Mrs: Adams spent the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s, and is quite unwell— Called again on Mr: Hudelist and gave him a second certificate.— Mr: Engel called on me.

6. Wrote a letter to my brother Thomas— In the Evening at the play— The two eldest Miss Brown’s went with us— King Theodore at Venice, an Opera, with Paësiello’s music. I saw it formerly at the Hague— It was better performed here. Mr: Arbuthnot came into our box.

7. Dr: Brown’s family, and Mr: Murray dined with us.— Mr: Arbuthnot called in the Evening. Count and Countess Brühl, and their daughter spent the Evening with us too.— Played chess with the Count. Spent the forenoon again idly.

8. Read the second book of Wieland’s Neue Amadis— In the Evening Madame d’Engeström paid a visit to Mrs: A. and introduced Countess Bünau the Saxon Minister’s lady.— Read the Doctor’s the Pardoner’s and the Shipman’s tale in Chaucer.

9. Mr: Murray called here in the forenoon— We spent the Evening at Doctor Brown’s, where I introduced him— We found there Count Brühl, and his family— M. d’Alvensleben, M. d’Anadia, Mr: Arbuthnot, and Mr: Curtoys— Played chess with Count Brühl— Had a lesson of German this morning— Made an extract of the first book of Wieland’s Oberon.

10. Mr: Murray dined with us. Spent the Evening at Bellevue— Prince Ferdinand himself has been for several months very dangerously ill, but is now recovering— Played whist with Madame de Bredow, Madame de Wangenheim, and the Comte de Meuron— I did not stay to supper. Continuing to make an extract from Wieland’s Oberon.

11. Stormed so hard the greatest part of the day that I could not go out— Snow all the afternoon. Extract from the third book of Oberon. Finished Chaucers tale of Melibeus— It is written very much in the manner of Dr: Franklin’s way to Wealth— Letter from Mr: Murray.

12. Mr: Engel here this forenoon. Dined at Count Haugwitz’s with a diplomatic company, of about twenty persons.— Upon my return home found Mrs: Schickler with Mrs: A.— Visits to Madame de Rosenkrantz, and Madame d’Engeström— Remainder of the Evening at home— Mrs: A. spent it at Mrs: Schickler’s.

13. German song for Mrs: A— Walking under the trees, met Mr: Garlike— Visit this Evening from Mr: Hudelist, who brought me a Passport for Mr: Murray— Latter part of the Evening at Doctor Brown’s— Played Chess with him. The Miss Brühl’s, and Mr: Arbuthnot there— Mr: Garlike too came in late—

14. Called this forenoon upon Mr: Murray, to give him his passport.— Mrs: A. very unwell— Mr: Garlike spent the Evening with me— Played Chess— Extract from the fourth book of Oberon— Lesson of German in the morning.

15. Wrote a short letter this forenoon— The two youngest Miss Browns spent the Evening with Mrs: A. Mr: Arbuthnot and Mr: Murray likewise called upon us. Weather fine— Still reading and extracting from the Oberon.

16. Letter to Mr: Murray— Met the Marquis de Lucchesini walking. Called in the Evening at Countess Brühl’s, but she was not at home— Pass’d it at Dr: Brown’s, where we found Count Brühl, and his family— Played Chess with him— Two more stanza’s of Oberon.

17. Finished the introduction of Oberon. Madame Ursinus paid a visit this afternoon to Mrs: A.— She lives over our heads in the same house— Read the Monk’s and the Nun’s Priest’s tale in Chaucer; the latter is very good, and has been revived by Dryden under the title of the Cock and the Fox. Made an extract of the 5th: book of Oberon.

18. Wrote part of a letter this forenoon.— Translated a couple more Stanza’s from Oberon— Read the second Nun’s and the Canon’s yeoman’s tale in Chaucer— The second is curious as it contains an account of the alchemist pursuits and frauds in common practice when the author wrote.

19 Called this morning at the Casino, to look in the monthly review for an account of the English translation of Oberon; but could not find the reviews themselves— Translated two more Stanza’s.— Mr: Garlike called on us this afternoon, to tell of a new revolution at Paris— Dr: Brown and his family were here in the Evening; and Mr: Arbuthnot— Played chess with Dr: Brown.

20.— Wrote a letter to Jos: Hall— Spent the Evening and supped at Mr: Schickler’s— Played whist, with Baron Krüdener, Count Wartensleben, and the Count de Meuron.— Stayed of course very late. Translated three Stanza’s of Oberon— In the original very fine ones—from the 12th: to the 15th:

21. Lesson of German this morning.— Two more stanza’s of Oberon— Mr: Murray who has been to spend several days at Potsdam, and returned last night, called to see us this Evening.— Read to Mrs A— Pope’s translation of the first book of the Iliad.

22. Walking under the trees this morning, I met Mr: Garlike, and walked sometime with him. Went this evening to the play, and saw Kotzebue’s Menschenhass und Reue.— Fleck, as the stranger, and Madame Unzelmann as Eulalia. I saw it better performed in Holland.—

23.— Lesson of German— Wrote letters in the forenoon— The stanza’s of Oberon, seem to grow more and more difficult.— I find it almost impossible with my leisure time to go through two Stanza’s a day— Mrs: A. call’d this evening at Mrs: Brown’s and at Countess Brühl’s—but return’d early. Read to her the second book of Pope’s Iliad.

24. Weather grows very cold— Mr: Murray dined with us. In the Evening, at Baron d’Engeströms ball, given upon the occasion of a prince royal being born in Sweden.— The house was illuminated, and the ball very splendid— Did not stay to supper— Play’d whist with Madam de Bredow, Countess Blumenthal, and Mr: Knoblauch— Did not get through my Stanza’s.

25. Received large packets of newspapers from America; but the letters did not come— Evening at Princess Henry’s; and supp’d there— Talk’d with the Marquis de Lucchesini about Frederic 2. Who he says at the very commencement of our Revolution said to him—“Les Américains ont échappé à l’Angleterre.”— He thought it a great fault that the English did not send a much larger force at once.— Lucchesini says, he was to have been the editor of Frederic’s works; but was employed just at that time by the successor, upon a mission relating to the league of German Princes.— That were several passages in the posthumous works that were omitted—particularly relating to the Empress of Russia, and to Prince Henry of Prussia, with whom the king was very much dissatisfied at one time, on account of a secret negotiation, which Prince Henry had undertaken for a cession of the Margraviates of Bayreuth and Anspach to him; during the war of 1779.— Zimmerman’s anecdotes are in general tolerably accurate he says—but often times receive a colour not belonging to them, from the author’s egotism.

26— Received this evening a visit from Mr O’Farril the new Spanish Minister and his Lady.— Miss Emily Zennert spent the evening with Mrs: A— As did likewise Mr: Murray.— Have not yet entirely retrieved the Stanza in arrear ever since Sunday.

27. Mrs: Adams went this afternoon to pay the usual visits with Mrs: O’Farril.— Spent the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s— Retrieved the Stanza’s in arrear— Play’d chess with Dr: Brown— Met before dinner the Chevalier d’Aguilar walking under the trees.

28. Lesson of German— At 2. afternoon called upon Mr: Murray, and carried him to Count Haugwitz’s where we dined— A diplomatic dinner to the Spanish Minister just arrived— Visit to Madame de Rosenkrantz, whom I find alone— To the spanish minister, where I found the Vicount d’Anadia, and the Comte de Lymar, late Portuguese Minister at Vienna, who is returning to Lisbon— Mr: Otto came in, while I was there— Latter part of the Evening at Dr: Brown’s; and played Chess with him.

29. Letters from the Secretary of State— Began an answer— Spent the evening at Baron Heinitz’s. Played whist with Madame de Heinitz, Madame de Grappendorf and Mr: Helbig.— I still continue my two Stanzas, from the first book of Wieland’s Oberon.

30. Lesson of German. Writing in the forenoon— Evening and supper at the Baron de Hagen’s. Play’d whist with Madame de Bischoffwerder, Mlle: de Hagen, and M: de Rothenburg.— We stayed to supper— Home, little before midnight.

p.hi: A. went with Madam O’Farril to the play. Received a letter from Mr: King— Latter part of the evening at Doctor Brown’s.

div.p: Day— Rise irregularly between 6 and 8.— Lesson of German till 10. breakfast— Spend the forenoon in writing letters— Walk from 2 to 3. Dine—translate a couple of Stanza’s from the Oberon.— Evening now for the most part abroad— Bed at about 11.
